questions.title: EM U5 p38 Gra2 passive forms
body: // CLOZE Complete the email with the correctactive or passive form of the verbs in brackets. Dear Julia, You'll never gesswhat
(happen)! Our lovey new car
(steal)! One day last week Jack went out to be yhe beach for a swim and as usualhe
(hide) the car keys in the toe of his shoe. When he came out ofthe water, he
(not notice) anythingsuspicious. It didn't look as if his clothes
(touch).When he started to put them on, however, he realised that the keys
(take) and when he got to the car park, of course, the car was gonetoo. The police say there is a gang of car thieves who
(know)to be operating in the area. They think Jack
(watch)as he arrived at the beach. The thieves saw where he had parked the car and thenwhere the keys
(hide). It was almost twoweeks ago now and although we hope it
(find), we'rebeginning to think we might never see it again. Well, that's all from me. Writesoon and tell me all your news. Love, Raquel

questions.title: U6 p61 GR 2 Future forms
body: Match the uses of future forms to the examples.

options.value: will (a promise) -> I won't tell anyone
will (an expert opinion) -> The roadwill be closed.
will (a decision made at the moment of speaking) -> I'll callGraham now, shall I?
going to (an opinion based on present evidence) -> She'sgone very pale – she's going to faint.
going to (a personal intention) -> I'mgoing to apply to university next year.
Present continuous (a planned event) ->They're getting married sometime next year.
Present simple (a timetabled event)-> The conference is in the first week of April.
Present simple (a time clausewith a future meaning) -> When you arrive at the airport, phone me.

questions.title: U4 p47 Rev1 Articles indefinite, definitie, zero (review)
body: Complete the textwith a/an, the or — (no article). After
incredible 859 daysand 6,000 miles, British explorer Ed Stafford became
firstman to walk
entire length of
Amazon. Hefinally reached
Atlantic in
Brazil twoand a half years after he started his epic adventure in
jungles of Peru. The final leg proved one of
mostchallenging, with Mr Stafford collapsing
few hours beforereaching his final destination. Mr Stafford fell out with his original walkingpartner Luke Collyer, 37,
outdoor activities instructor, andafter only three months, Mr Collyer returned to
UK. MrStafford advertised for
walking partner and was joined bySanchez Rivera,
Peruvian forestry worker. Living off
piranha and rice, they made their way through Peru, Colombiaand Brazil. Mr Stafford said on Monday, ‘All I want now is
portion of fish and chips and
nice cold beer’.

questions.title: U4 p47 Rev1 Articles indefinite, definitie, zero (review)
body: Complete the textwith a/an, the or — (no article). After
incredible 859 daysand 6,000 miles, British explorer Ed Stafford became
firstman to walk
entire length of
Amazon. Hefinally reached
Atlantic in
Brazil twoand a half years after he started his epic adventure in
jungles of Peru. The final leg proved one of
mostchallenging, with Mr Stafford collapsing
few hours beforereaching his final destination. Mr Stafford fell out with his original walkingpartner Luke Collyer, 37,
outdoor activities instructor, andafter only three months, Mr Collyer returned to
UK. MrStafford advertised for
walking partner and was joined bySanchez Rivera,
Peruvian forestry worker. Living off
piranha and rice, they made their way through Peru, Colombiaand Brazil. Mr Stafford said on Monday, ‘All I want now is
portion of fish and chips and
nice cold beer’.

questions.title: U6 p64 5 Future-perfect-&-continuous
body: Read the rest of the article and choosethe correct option. I think by 2050 we'll
anincreasing number of 3D films. Film-makers may even
a way to project our faces onto the characters onthe screen by that time. I think here in Hollywood we will still
films — I don't think any other country will
us as the film-making centre of the world.

questions.title: U3 p33 Gra as/like GR3
body: Match the following clauses to make sentences.

options.value: Ihave long dark hair, -> like my sister.
He's always losing things, -> like hisphone and his keys.
I suggested going shopping, -> but she didn't feel like it.
She says she doesn't feel like -> doing anything tonight.
Buying a new printerlooks -> like the best solution to the problem.
I've always thought of you ->as someone I could depend on.
It's probably best to do -> as your fathersuggests.
Conor acts -> as if he was in charge of us all.

questions.title: U4 p47 Rev4 Past tenses, past perfect
body: Complete the second sentence so that ithas a similar meaning to the first sentence, using the word given. Use betweentwo and five words, including the word given. I lived in London until I gotmarried last year. BEEN I
in London until I got marriedlast year. It took three days for us to walk there. WERE We
three days. I couldn't remember the way there, so I got a taxi. FORGOTTEN I
get there, so I got a taxi. It was three yearssince I'd visited Peru. NOT I
toPeru for three years.

questions.title: U3 p33 Gra as/like GR3
body: Match the following clauses to make sentences.

options.value: Ihave long dark hair, -> like my sister.
He's always losing things, -> like hisphone and his keys.
I suggested going shopping, -> but she didn't feel like it.
She says she doesn't feel like -> doing anything tonight.
Buying a new printerlooks -> like the best solution to the problem.
I've always thought of you ->as someone I could depend on.
It's probably best to do -> as your fathersuggests.
Conor acts -> as if he was in charge of us all.

questions.title: U5 p50 0/4 Text
body: Read the text and fill in each gap with a single word. It can be an expressionof quantity for some of the gaps.WHY DO PEOPLE LOVE CHILLI?People don't wash their eyes in lemon juice or pour boiling hot tea overthemselves, so why are we prepared to go through so much pain for the sake ofchilli?Chilli is not the only strange thing that people seem to enjoy. For example,very
people like the bitter taste of coffee to begin with but soonmost of us
used to it. But coffee contains caffeine,which has some addictive qualities, and this explains
it is sopopular. But capsaicin, the ingredient which makes chillies hot, does not seemto have
addictive qualities whatsoever.
we consumed alarge quantity of it, it would kill us. And yet chillies have
usedin cooking in almost
culture for thousands of years. Today, athird of the world's population eat chilli at least once a day. Lots of ourfavourite dishes just wouldn't taste right
it.// Exercise 2: Multiple Choice

questions.title: U5 p52 3.1 Reading compr
body: Why did Rob Rhinehart initially create Soylent?

options.value: He saw it as a way of earning money to support his new company.
He felt thatcooking was taking up too much of his time.
He wanted to live on a diet ofnutritious food.
He thought that he would be able to live more cheaply.
